title: Tropical Storm Debby may bring  catastrophic  flooding to South Carolina amid  multiday deluge
message:
SOUTH CAROLINA (WBTV) - The South Carolina Emergency Management Division is monitoring Tropical Storm Debby as forecasters predict the storm will move “very slowly” across the state this week, leading to potentially historic rainfall.
Key local and state agencies have been notified to be ready to respond if the need arises, SCEMD officials announced Monday.

title: Hurricane Debby to bring heavy rains and catastropic flooding to Florida , Georgia and S . Carolina

Tropical Storm Debby hits Florida with floods, threat of record rain in Georgia and the CarolinasHORSESHOE BEACH, Fla. (AP) — Tropical Storm Debby slammed Florida with torrential rain and high winds, contributing to at least four deaths as it turned menacingly toward the Eastern Seaboard’s low-lying regions and threatened to flood some of America’s most historic Southern cities.
The potential for high water threatened Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina.
It has since weakened to a tropical storm and is moving slowly, covering roads with water and contributing to at least four deaths.
In South Carolina, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a “historic and potentially unprecedented event” three times in a 90-second briefing Monday morning.
North Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than $1 billion in damage.

title: Opinion : Why there is no such thing as a  natural  disaster
message:
Charting a safer, more resilient course means first acknowledging that there is no such thing as a “natural disaster.” The word “natural” implies these events are entirely out of our control, thereby absolving us of the responsibility to prepare and reduce risk from natural hazards.
When we destroy and degrade much of the natural world, we make communities more vulnerable to disasters.
Without the storage capacity these natural systems provide, the risk of devastating floods and landslides increases.
Anita van Breda - WWFNature is fundamental to supporting life on Earth, adapting to a changing climate and reducing disaster risk.
In the wake of Hurricane Stan in 2005, Guatemala and Mexico diversified their farming systems to improve resilience and reduce future disaster risk.

title: Tropical storm Debby expected to intensify into hurricane , poses threat to Florida gulf coast
message:

message:
Debby turned deadly as it continues to roar across Florida after it made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane Monday morning.

title: Tropical Storm Debby strengthens into a Category 1 hurricane as it heads toward Florida | News , Sports , Jobs
message:

Debby is the fourth named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season after Tropical Storm Alberto, Hurricane Beryl and Tropical Storm Chris, all of which formed in June.

title: Debby Intensifies Into Hurricane , Moves Toward Florida Gulf Coast
message:
Tropical Storm Debby intensified into a Category 1 hurricane as it continues to move toward the Big Bend stretch of Florida's Gulf Coast ahead of expected landfall Monday (August 5) morning, CBS News reports.
Debby is the fourth named storm reported during Atlantic hurricane season, the National Hurricane Center announced on Saturday (August 3).
The agency predicted Debby would bring drenching rain and coastal flooding, which would begin Sunday (August 4) night.
"There is a danger of life-threatening storm surge along portions of the Gulf Coast of Florida, with 6 to 10 feet of inundation above ground level expected somewhere between Ochlockonee River to Yankeetown late tonight and Monday morning," the National Hurricane Center wrote at around 11:00 p.m.
"Residents in the Storm Surge Warning area should follow any advice given by local officials."

title: Hurricane Slams Florida After Gaining Fury in Warm Waters
message:
Hurricane Debby slammed into Florida southeast of Tallahassee as a Category 1 storm after intensifying over warm waters, the latest evidence that this will be a robust season for tropical cyclones.
Months of record warm water across the Atlantic has raised alarm that 2024 would be a very hurricane active season.
Debby is already the second storm to make landfall in the US this year following Beryl, which struck eastern Texas last month and caused a massive power outage.
A year ago, Hurricane Idalia made landfall in the Big Bend area as a Category 3 hurricane.
Photo: Protective measures at a business ahead of Hurricane Debby in Cedar Key, Florida, US, on Aug. 4.

title: As storm Debby strengthens , US southeast braces for  historic  rainfall
message:
Florida Governor Ron DeSantis said that some 250,000 residents in his state were without power as of Monday morning (JOE RAEDLE)At least four people were killed as Tropical Storm Debby drenched Florida on Monday, threatening southeastern US states with heavy rainfall and catastrophic flooding.
The storm is expected to move into Georgia overnight, before moving offshore and approaching the South Carolina coast on Thursday, according to the National Hurricane Center (NHC).
Storm surge warnings -- signalling a life-threatening inundation from rising water -- are in effect in parts of Georgia, South Carolina and North Carolina.
The governors of Georgia and South Carolina have declared a state of emergency ahead of the storm's arrival.
Meanwhile, the US Border Patrol announced that Debby had washed up 25 packages of cocaine to the coast of the Florida Keys, where they were seized.

title: Major flooding possible in SC as Hurricane Debby is forecast to drench Columbia area
message:
Major flooding possible in SC as Tropical Storm Debby is forecast to drench Columbia areaTropical Storm Debby made landfall in the U.S. on Monday, and will move north toward the Columbia area of South Carolina, where a flood watch has been issued, according to the National Weather Service.
The storm was expected to affect the Midlands area Monday night and continue through Tuesday and Wednesday, National Weather Service meteorologists said in a morning briefing.
Excessive runoff could result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations, according to the National Weather Service.
As of Sunday night, Debby’s winds are not expected to be a major threat to the Columbia area, the National Weather Service said.
The possibility of tornadoes cannot be ruled out, as a limited threat remains, according to the National Weather Service.

The centre of Tropical Storm Debby will move across the eastern Gulf of Mexico and reach the Florida Big Bend coast this morning, it added.
Debby is then expected to move slowly across northern Florida and southern Georgia today and tomorrow, it said.
A tropical storm warning is in effect for extreme southern Florida, stretching as far north as the Fort Myers area crushed by Hurricane Ian in 2022.

title: Debby approaches South Carolina , threatening  historic  rain
message:
Areas from Savannah to Charleston could see 10-20 inches of rain across the region, with localized amounts as high as 30 inches, over the next few days.
The National Weather Service is warning that the potentially historic levels of rainfall could result in severe and catastrophic flooding.
The heaviest rain is expected to last at least until Aug. 8, though it could extend beyond that.
Officials said that some areas of the state could experience rainfall amounts they've never experienced, especially in the Lowcountry.
A similar effect happened with an October 2015 storm system, resulting in what would become known as the "thousand-year flood."

title: Maps show Hurricane Debby path and forecast
message:
Tropical Storm Debby was barreling across northern Florida on Monday after making landfall over the state's Big Bend coast as a Category 1 hurricane.
Even with the slight dip in intensity, Debby was forecast to bring dangerous storm surge to parts of the Gulf Coast of Florida through Monday afternoon.
Storm surge threats gradually lessened as the hours passed after Debby's landfall, with forecasters saying by the afternoon that peak surge in that region would look more like 3 to 5 feet.
The National Hurricane Center published maps on Monday illustrating the storm surge forecast.
Coastal places as far south as Bonita Beach could see heavy rainfall coupled with storm surge for the next several days as a result of the tropical storm.

title: The Latest : Debby knocks out power to hundreds of thousands in Florida , Georgia
message:
No evacuations planned for now in South Carolina, officials sayState officials don’t plan any evacuations in South Carolina for now as Tropical Storm Debby slowly spins toward the state.
Biden approves request from South Carolina's governor for emergency declarationThe White House said Monday that President Joe Biden has approved a request from South Carolina Gov.
Flooding and power outages are expected to start Tuesday and continue through the rest of the week, according to North Carolina Emergency Management officials.
Debby made landfall in Florida on Monday as a Category 1 hurricane and was expected to bring potentially record-setting rainfall to Georgia and South Carolina as it heads east.
Forecasters are still warning that heavy rain could spawn catastrophic flooding in Florida, South Carolina and Georgia.

title: Debby strengthens to Category 1 hurricane , expected to make landfall in Florida
message:
Hurricane Debby made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane on Monday morning, with winds of 80mph and after forecasters had warned of life-threatening storm surges and widespread flooding.
A hurricane warning is in place for Florida's Gulf Coast, from Yankeetown to Indian Pass, while large parts of the state's coastline are under a tropical storm warning and storm surge watches.
Joe Raedle / Getty ImagesThe hurricane is forecast to bring a storm surge of 2 to 10 feet in certain areas, and heavy rain through Friday morning.
The University of South Florida in St. Petersberg and the University of Florida in Gainesville, in the northern half of the state, said they would be closed Monday.
DeSantis compared Debby’s path to that of Hurricane Idalia, the Category 4 storm that caused significant damage in north Florida last year.

title: Hurricane Debby could bring heavy rain to much of NC this week . Here when and where .
message:
Tropical Storm Debby could bring heavy rain to much of NC this week.
Update: Debby, which was first categorized as a hurricane, weakened to a tropical storm around 11 a.m. Monday.
From there it’s expected to move north into North Carolina, still a tropical storm.
Flash flooding is possible in all but extreme western North Carolina this week as what becomes Tropical Storm Debby moves slowly over the Southeast.
Along the coast, dangerous storm surge and wind impacts are expected from Florida all the way to North Carolina through midweek.

title: Cooper declares state of emergency ahead of Debby
message:
RALEIGH, N.C. (WITN) - Governor Roy Cooper last this afternoon declared a state of emergency ahead of the remnants of Hurricane Debby hitting the state.
Cooper said the storm has the potential for life-threatening flash flooding, river flooding, wind gusts up to 40 miles per hour, and coastal impacts.
“This weather has the potential to bring intense rain and flooding to North Carolina and we are preparing for it,” said Governor Cooper.
“As the weather becomes more severe, I urge everyone to take precautions and stay safe.”The executive order activates the State Emergency Operations Plan and allows state agencies to take action that ensures the movement of utility vehicles and those carrying essential supplies to get where they need to be.

title: Tropical Storm Debby blew $1 million worth of cocaine onto Florida Keys beach , Border Patrol says
message:
Tropical Storm Debby blew $1 million worth of cocaine onto Florida Keys beach, Border Patrol saysAs thousands of Floridians braced for the impact of Tropical Storm Debby on Monday, Border Patrol seized dozens of packages of cocaine.
The storm's outer skirt brought high winds and storms to the Florida Keys Monday morning.
Authorities received a call from a Good Samaritan saying he found drug packages on a Florida Keys beach.
Border Patrol officers seized 70 pounds of cocaine on the beach that had blown out by Tropical Storm Debby.

title: Travel impacted by Debby as deadly storm forces thousands of flight cancellations , delays
message:
Debby, which was downgraded from a hurricane to tropical storm after making landfall along Florida's Big Bend, was impacting travel across the U.S. starting over the weekend.
Is my flight to Florida canceled because of Debby?
(FOX Weather)With now-Troical Storm Debby continuing to funnel in damaging winds and flooding rain to Florida and the Southeast, thousands of flights have once again been impacted.
And as deadly Tropical Storm Debby slowly creeps farther north, flights are now being impacted at Charlotte Douglas International Airport (CLT) in the mid-Atlantic.

title: Images of flooding from Topical Storm Debby
message:
While it will hit North Florida, it left serious flooding in its wake as it passed Southwest Florida as a tropical storm.
The storm moved up the Gulf of Mexico Sunday, and though the center of the storm’s circulation was off land, Southwest Florida received several inches of rainfall.
The county saw numerous road closures throughout the day.
To the south, Collier County saw bridges closed in Marco Island and Naples.
By nighttime, the worst of the storm had passed, but forecasters caution that’s not to rule out powerful cells of rain and wind from the outer bands of the storm as it continues moving northward.

title: Horry County moves to OPCON2 in preparation for Debby
message:
Horry County moved to OPCON2 Monday ahead of Hurricane Debby's arrival in the Carolinas.
The move means the county is operating in a "heightened state of awareness with emergency plans beginning to be implemented."
The Horry County Emergency Operations Center is not currently activated, however, action will be taken as necessary.

title: Weather Evacuations : Tropical Storm Debby to Become Hurricane , Make Florida Landfall by Monday
message:
Tropical Storm Debby could be upgraded to hurricane status by Monday as it heads toward Florida from the Gulf of Mexico, weather officials have predicted.
Portions of Southwest Florida are already feeling the storm’s impact even before it makes it to land, with officials issuing tornado warnings, watches, and evacuations as the wind and rainfall pick up, FOX Weather reported.
According to the National Hurricane Center (NHC), there is danger of a “life-threatening storm surge” along parts of Florida’s Gulf Coast, with six to ten feet of flooding expected between the Ochlockonee and Suwanee Rivers.
“You have a few more hours to get to a safe place before conditions begin to deteriorate by this evening,” Brennan warned, before explaining that Debby is set to flood other parts of the southeastern U.S. after Florida.
The NHC is “especially concerned” about the area from Savannah, Georgia, and up through Charleston, South Carolina, to Myrtle Beach due to “excessive rainfall,” the weather expert added.

title: Hurricane Debby makes landfall in northern Florida as Category 1 storm – Times News Online
message:
TAMPA, Fla. (AP) — Hurricane Debby has made landfall Monday in northern Florida as a Category 1 storm.
The storm made landfall in one of the least populated areas of Florida, but forecasters warned heavy rain could spawn catastrophic flooding in Florida, South Carolina and Georgia.
The sparsely populated Big Bend region in the Florida Panhandle also was hit last year by Hurricane Idalia, which made landfall as a Category 3 hurricane.
Debby is the fourth named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season after Tropical Storm Alberto, Hurricane Beryl and Tropical Storm Chris, all of which formed in June.

title: Tropical Storm Debby sending storms , increased flood risk for the Carolinas
message:
After seeing mostly sunny skies during the day we have seen a couple of isolated thunderstorms this evening.
The focus though of the upcoming week will be Tropical Storm Debby and the track of the storm.
As for tonight and Monday, isolated thunderstorms this evening will fade overnight with lows in the low 70s.
From there the storm is expected to move slowly northward along the Georgia and Carolina coast and potentially stall.
The storm should finally clear out Friday night with drier weather expected over the week along with warmer temperatures rebounding back toward the low 90s.
